awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Improving user trust of autonomous vehicles through human-vehicle collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
Fully autonomous vehicles (FAVs) represent a key future direction for transportation, especially for populations who are currently disenfranchised by traditional, manually operated vehicles, such as those with visual impairments or older adults.  Unfortunately, the benefits of self-driving technology for these demographics have yet to be adequately considered in the design of FAVs. This concern is part of a larger problem in which the majority of people simply do not trust that self-driving cars will meet their needs. This project explores new ways to share decision-making information between people and FAVs. Instead of existing systems where the FAV makes the decisions in a "black box" way that users don't see or understand, the project will develop a Human-Vehicle Collaboration (HVC) framework in which effective communication about the vehicle's decision-making process improves users' sense of agency and decisions around trusting the FAV. Through studying people's reactions to and understanding of FAV driving decisions and developing algorithms and interfaces that help FAVs communicate in ways that address them, the HVC framework will promote appropriate levels of trust in FAVs for all users, while providing substantial benefits around improving accessibility for under-served populations.  

The HVC framework will be designed and evaluated using a high-fidelity driving simulator that tests new interaction methods for sharing information during key driving events. Research will use this simulator and experimental platform to manipulate a host of variables relating to decision states while driving. Human data will be collected on reaction time, interpretation of vehicle decision-making, physiological measures based on galvanic skin response and heart rate, as well as pre-post survey measures for assessing trust in fully-autonomous vehicles. Results will form the foundation for developing and testing HVC profiles that provide individualized interactions and collaborations during driving events. These profiles and the resulting guidelines represent a key deliverable for the project as they will be designed from the outset to improve trust, accessibility, and the overall optimization of fully-autonomous vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project consisted of several user studies, surveys, and development work conceptualized within a framework of assessing user trust of fully autonomous vehicles (FAVs) through the lens of Human-Vehicle Collaboration (HVC). Our goals focused on: (1) gaining insight from potential users (with an emphasis on driving limited populations such as the blind and visually impaired community and older adults) on how their perceptions of FAVs may affect their overall trust of the technology, (2) understanding how and what information is communicated between a FAV and the user to support safe and efficient interactions, and (3) using these results to develop a high-fidelity driving simulator for supporting inclusive user studies.

 

Substantial time, resources, and effort were spent during this project developing a new, custom-built, FAV simulator called MOISIN (Multimodal Omnidirectional Immersive Simulator for Inclusive Navigation). This is the first full-motion and fully autonomous “people mover” or “robo-taxi” simulator in North America. It was designed to simulate the type of multi-person passenger FAVs anticipated to replace current human-driven taxis or ridesharing services (see Figure 1) and to serve as a multisensory research platform for studying trust, user needs, interface development, and inclusive design for use in this next era of transportation.

 

Over the course of this project, we conducted several user studies to fulfill our goals. These included evaluating blind and visually impaired users’ needs and concerns regarding autonomous vehicle usage and trust with respect to information access, evaluating the extent to which self-reported trust matches intention-to-use behavior in FAVs, and developing/evaluating new inclusive mechanisms and multisensory user interfaces involving natural language, touch and haptics, and enhanced visual displays supporting communication between the user and the FAV (and vice versa). Outcomes from this project resulted in assessing and implementing novel tools supporting inclusive research with intelligent and autonomous transportation systems, exploring how to increase user trust of these vehicles, and incorporating user input into new interfaces needed to support safe and efficient vehicle operation and interaction. The newly developed MOISIN simulator also represents a robust research platform for advancing the study of accessible and inclusive transportation that can be used by a wide range of researchers and stakeholders.

 

The broader impacts of increased accessibility in autonomous transportation allow enhanced mobility and independence among the millions of people experiencing transportation limiting disabilities. Enthusiasm from participants throughout the project’s work was reflective of these potential impacts and speaks to how conveying vehicle information and enhancing human-in-the-loop control are critical to this technology moving forward. Fully autonomous vehicles represent a key future direction for transportation, especially for the driving-limited populations who were the focus of this project, and the research carried out here provided critical understanding and guidance on how to improve trust, human-vehicle collaboration, and interactions using new inclusive, multisensory approaches that will be important for use in these systems as they continue to development and be deployed on our roads.
